jdm.name: LinkedIn
jdm.notes: There are reports that LinkedIn continues to email people with a closed account. You may need to contact customer services to delete account instead of just closing it.

topics.description: The content and the data you generate on services online is usually subject to copyright law. When your data are collected by services, they can be considered personal data.  It means that it is your content, your data: you can decide.

example.bad: We get a license beyond the requirements to operate the service, so your data may be used for purposes you do not intend. We will still attribute ownership to you.
example.blocker: We become the owners of your data.
example.good: You license us to use your data only for the purpose of operating this service.

topics.name: Ownership
topics.subtitle: What happens with the content you generate on the service?
topics.title: Ownership

tosdr.tldr: Your LinkedIn profile may be used to target suggestions on other platforms owned by LinkedIn - like SlideShare.

meta.author: Greer Hahn

points.title: Selective data used to monetize the service

tosdr.tldr: Whilst LinkedIn makes an express promise not to sell or rent your personal information (for example, your profile), the data you generate by using the service (every post, connection, interaction, group you join and so on) provides LinkedIn with a mass of other valuable data. They leverage this data to sell their paid for and other premium subscriptions to companies, recruiters and so on. The licence you grant them when you sign up allows them to use the data in this way.

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

topics.name: Cookies
topics.subtitle: and related technologies
topics.title: Cookies

tosdr.tldr: Unless you expressly opt out, LinkedIn's advertisers and other third parties can collect and use information abut you via web beacons, cookies and other technologies. This information could include your IP address, the type of device you use, the web sites you visit and even your location.

topics.description: The terms sometimes describe the level of logging and the level of data collection and which kinds of data the service is processing. Anonymity or the right to use a pseudonym can be very important for freedom of expression (e.g. for people exercising a certain profession, or people living in authoritarian regimes).

topics.name: Anonymity and Tracking
topics.subtitle: Are you being spied on?
topics.title: Anonymity and Tracking

tosdr.case: pseudonym not allowed (not because of user-to-user trust)
tosdr.tldr: You must use your legal name publicly on this service. Using a pseudonym or a pen name is not allowed. This can negatively impact your freedom of expression, especially for those with certain professions, or who live in certain countries.

topics.name: Cookies
topics.subtitle: and related technologies
topics.title: Cookies

tosdr.tldr: LinkedIn sets and uses cookies on your computer. This gives LinkedIn both identifiable (when you are signed in) and anonymous (when you are signed out) forms of information about you, your preferences and behaviour. You can choose to reject all cookies in your browser but this may prevent you from using LinkedIn services they require you to sign in. To track you on other LinkedIn Services’ sites and across the web, LinkedIn may also use web beacons that act in a similar way to cookies and gather and contain information about your web browsing behaviour.

topics.name: Guarantee
topics.subtitle: Some services will guarantee you certain features, or explicitly reject any guarantee.
topics.title: Guarantee

tosdr.tldr: In certain circumstances, such as your failure to comply with the terms of service, your account could be cancelled, or your use of the service limited, without notice to you.

points.title: Terms may be changed at any time, but they will notify you in advance

topics.description: Services need to evolve. But it is important that updating the service does not break the consentment with the user. Updates and changes to terms of service and privacy policy need to be properly noticed to users and to sollicit their agreement again.

topics.name: Notice of Changing Terms
topics.subtitle: Are users notified when terms change? Are they given enough time to find out what changed and discuss this with each other before deciding whether to continue to use the service under the new terms?
topics.title: Notice of Changing Terms

tosdr.case: user is notified on the day
tosdr.tldr: This service may change the terms at any time, but they will notify the user - typically via email or their apps. Your continued use of the service is taken as acceptance of the new or changed terms.

points.title: Personal information will generally be deleted within 30 days

topics.description: Once you subscribe to the service, will you have the right to leave it and remove your data?

topics.name: Right to leave the service
topics.subtitle: To avoid lock-in and stay in control
topics.title: Right to leave the service

tosdr.tldr: Whilst your account and personal information may be deleted within 30 days, LinkedIn can retain your personal information if they deem it 'reasonably necessary' to comply with legal, regulatory, fraud, dispute or abuse matters.

topics.name: Law and government requests
topics.subtitle: How do services deal with government requests?
topics.title: Law and government requests

tosdr.tldr: This service informs users when their data is sought by the government, unless prohibited by law. With this knowledge, you have an opportunity to involve yourself if you think the request is unreasonable.

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.

meta.license-for-this-file: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ or send a letter to Creative Commons, 444 Castro Street, Suite 900, Mountain View, California, 94041, .USA

topics.name: Scope of the copyright license
topics.subtitle: Do you grant only the necessary rights?
topics.title: Scope of the copyright license

tosdr.tldr: The copyright license you grant is limited by time i.e. it ends when you delete your content or account. However, it allows LinkedIn to use, copy, modify, distribute, publish, and process your information and content for as long as you use the service or have an account, without any further notice or compensation to you.
